Calculus, a branch of mathematics, was developed in the 17th century by two renowned mathematicians, Sir Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz. The term âcalculusâ comes from Latin and means âsmall pebble used for counting.âÂ

Calculus is the mathematical study of continuous change and is divided into two branches: differential calculus and integral calculus.Â

Differential calculus focuses on the concept of a derivative, which can be thought of as how a function changes as its input changes.Â

Integral calculus, on the other hand, involves the concept of an integral, which can be thought of as the area under a curve. Calculus plays a pivotal role in various fields such as physics, engineering, economics, computer science, and more. It helps us understand the changes between values that are related by a function.
